title: CupCake X-Stage Webcam Mount for Logitech C510

description.text: I often stream video of my CupCake in action (especially when I'm printing objects for friends) and wanted a way to mount the webcam so it followed the action. I came up with this very simple design in OpenSCAD. It needs some adjusting as the slot for the cam was a little tight (although it held the cam firmly) and the base was a little thin (so I wrapped it in a layer of duct tape). All the sizes are set by parameters so it should be easy to tweak. I thought the cam might shake with the movement but it didn't as far as I could tell. Because the cam is mounted on the X-axis it makes the extruder look like it's moving left and right as well as up and down. The only other problem is that this model of cam only has a fixed focus. As you can see from the action shot it looks like it's focused on the HBP wires at the back. I might try redesigning it to make the cam sit a bit higher and further away from the build platform. I don't want it to be too high however as its current size makes it easy to fold up and stay mounted but out of the way when not in use or when needing to access the build platform. Another idea would be to mount it on the back of the X-Stage. That way it could be taller without getting in the way. A mashup between this and reprapperMC's mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8571) could be in order. :)

• Print
  • Fit webcam into mount
  • Attach mount onto X-Stage
  • Stream on ustream.tv or similar
  • Profit?

comments.text: Where do you stream your video?
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: On USTREAM (http://www.ustream.tv/)http://www.ustream.tv/). It's Flash-based so doesn't require any extra software and allows you to record your videos as well. They also have an Android app (and iPhone too I assume) so you can watch your own printer when you're in another room.

This is a leadscrew block for a TR8 4 start 2mm pitch lead screw (the most common ones used in 3D printers today)
The block is anti-backlash by design.
The part is designed to be printed out of IGUS tribo-filament, but works great in PLA as well. Just print a few as they do wear out more.
Dimensional drawing and STEP included if you want to incorporate it into your design. Please mind the usual 3D printing tolerances. You don't want to squeeze the part and make it too tight on the lead screw. When in doubt, design for loser fit on the sides, and tighter fit around the 2 aligning protrusions.
The block is pressed into the retainer that both provides mounting options, and gives rigidity.

An animated helicopter pull, push, downhill toy. The main and tail rotors spin as this toy is pushed, pulled or sent down a hill. I printed the prototype gear trains in various colors and designed an open cockpit in order to highlight the operation of gears both beveled and linear to up and coming engineers. Video of the prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0c_GuncghxQ. My wonderful wife, sister in law, kids, grandkids, nieces and nephews had fun producing the video and audio. Hope you and yours like it as did I. I'm printing more of these things for them, schools, and labs. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Supports are optional, depending on your printer and settings, for printing "Nose.stl" and "Tail.stl". Mine printed fine without supports.

Study "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".  Supports are optional, depending on your printer and settings, for printing "Nose.stl" and "Tail.stl".  My prototypes printed fine without supports. 
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.
Place wide rubber bands around the circumference of all wheels for traction.
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Apply light machine oil on the moving parts.
To make a pull toy, slip a length of yarn into the lower front hole in "Nose.stl", tie a large knot, secure it with glue, then pull the yarn back so that the knot rests against the inside of the hole.
Once fully assembled, tested and aligned, a small dot of thick cyanoacrylate glue between the gears and axles will aid in holding the gears in position.
Feel free to comment if you have questions.
Hope you like it!

title: Large Kossel M8 Threaded Rod Braces for 1515 OpenBeam (like Kossel XL kit from builda3dprinter.eu)

description.text:
I purchased a large Kossel kit with long 1515 openbeam extrusions. Unfortunately it's not very rigid. These braces use M8 threaded rod to massively increase rigidity. The STLs provided work for beam length 360mm wide and 750mm high. If your beams are different lengths, download the scad file and adjust the parameters. You will get new STLs and also the console will output how long you should cut your M8 threaded rod (for 750x360 that's 804mm). Bill Of Materials (for bracing all 3 sides):
  • M8 threaded rod (length dependent on beam length) qty 6
  • M8 Nut qty 12
  • M3*8mm machine screw qty 24
  • M3 nut qty 24
  • M3 wash qty 24

author: RichRap

description.text:
Here is my first contribution. I wanted a way to support the spool that was easy to change spools, offered little resistance to rolling, and was cheap to build. I used almost an entire ten-foot piece of 3/4" schedule 40 PVC, four elbows, four roller-blade bearings (I had those lying around), four 5/16 bolts, washers, and nylon locknuts. 
I printed two of the spool guides, because I didn't want the spool walking along the pipe and possibly falling off. I printed four of the pipe-to-bearings, used a c-clamp to press the bearings into them. I printed two of the pipe-to-rollers, and bolted the bearings to them using 5/16 inch socket head cap bolts, washers, and nylock nuts. Then I pressed the back side of the bearing fitting into the PVC that goes across the top, and pressed the pipe-to-roller pieces into the vertically-oriented piece of PVC pipe.
The front printer brace goes over the pipe, and under the front of the printer base, to hold the whole system in place, together with the printer, adding stability.
Cut the PVC to lengths that make sense for your printer.
I have attached not only the STL files, but also the blend files (and one in 123d format, because I was trying that out). Let me know if you make one!

This buttons I made for our son with Mild Cerebral palsy for him to train to use his left arm.
Cause of his contition and weakness in the left arm he don't use it at all and he hasnt done the past 4 years before we adopted him.
So to learn him that he CAN use his arm at least and make use of it, even a little.. we have to practice to get better..
And hopeful in the future he will be able to make more use with his arm..
But for now this is a way to activate him to use his left arm.

It works as simple as you have to push both buttons down to get a signal. what the signal should start is up to you to decide.
For now I just added a beep signal but I got a hold of a circuit from an old toy that blinks and cheers when activated so that will go in soon ;)

You need 2 small micro switches that you can get in any DIY electronics store..
Image below, and it should measure 6mm in height without legs.
Then you need some thin cables and a power supply like a battery.
Solder required To get the function of two hand command, that you need to push both buttons to get the signal you just connect the switches in series.

• you have a battery with + and -
  • Connect one cable to battery + and the other end on one leg of the first switch.
  • From the same switch you continue to the next switch with a new cable.
  • And from the second switch you pull a new piece of wire to your "sond signal" or "flashing led" and make sure to connect it to that components or circuits + side.
  • The - side of the component or circuit goes directly to the battery -minus side
    • Test the circuit before installing all the cables in the parts ;)

description.text: This is a screen case for the Qualia (iPad 2) screen and displayport driver board available from Adafruit. The screen is held in by friction, and holds quite well. 8 Screws join the perimeter, and one for the handle. Three buttons on the back are functional, though I did not include access for the power switch. This includes a mount plate at 5cm, though it can be resized as you see fit. Also included is a modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:203420 (scredriver handle) to allow this to be handheld. It's just the handle, simplified and joined with the backing plate. Works pretty well. It was designed as a handheld close-in monitor for detailed design work so I wouldn't have to lean in to see my monitor during fine manipulations. It also functions as a secondary monitor during other times. Whatever you want to use it for. Printed on a modified Printrbot Metal Simple.

I enjoy experimenting with, building, and flying radio control airplanes made out of Dollar Tree foam board. Most RC flyers have heard about and probably have flown the FT Bloody Wonder. One thing that I really wanted with these Dollar Tree foam board airplanes was a landing gear. I happened across a plastic landing gear bracket at the local hobby store, but it was almost $12.00(US). I decided to make my own and tailor it to Dollar Tree foam board. The picture shows the landing gear brackets installed parallel to the wing and perpendicular to the body of the airplane with the wheels on the outside of the brackets. If I wanted the landing gear closer to the body I could have bent the strut wire that holds the wheels to the inside. You can also install the landing gear brackets parallel to the body and have the landing gear under the belly of the airplane if you want. There are many ways to install the bracket and many more on how to bend the struts to make the wheels closer to the body or even further away. One strut, parallel to the body, with a single wheel would make a great tail gear. Instructions:
1) I make my struts out of stock #505 (3/32" or 2.38mm) music wire, you can find this in most hobby stores.
2) To make the strut, as shown in the picture, bend that wire as shown in the illustration above with 90 degree angles.
  • Install a wheel with collars. I like to use Du-Bro 3/32" Plated Brass Dura Collars (Cat No 596)
    3) When you install the hex keepers on the collars add a dap of blue Thread Locker.
    4) The struts can be installed on the brackets with zip ties, epoxy, or hot glue. I prefer zip ties for easy removal.
    5) Press the strut with landing gear into the foam board to note where the strut hole and zip ties mark the foam.
    6) Use a hobby knife to cut out the holes for the strut and zip ties so the bracket will lie flat.
    7) Hot glue the bracket to the foam board.
    • Note: The airplane shown in the pictures doesn't and was never intended to fly, its a test bed for software/hardware designs.

author: Makersome

print_settings.Notes:: Whatever you do with the printing, make sure that there are loads of solid layers on the top as you'll likely be sanding slightly into the surface of the part after glassing the plug in.

description.text: A selection of surfboard plugs for attaching a surfboard leash to a surfboard. The _thin file totals 13mm depth, while all the other ones have a depth of 15mm.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.3 mm

Infill:

80 - 100%

Notes: For best appearance - print as oriented in the STL. Just remember that prints tend to be weakest along the layers so a hard pull on the leash will apply most of the stress on the weakest characteristic of the part. For best strength - flip on it's side and print with support. It might not look quite as nice though. Whatever you do with the printing, make sure that there are loads of solid layers on the top as you'll likely be sanding slightly into the surface of the part after glassing the plug in. I'll be aiming for big overlaps between infill and perimeters and printing with solid layers every so often just to ensure that it's well sealed. There shouldn't be any real need to completely seal the unit for waterproofing if your resin pour is effective -- but it can't hurt, just in case. Finally, just consider the temperature characteristics of the plastic that you'll be using before glassing it into your board - boards can get hot in cars which could be trouble if printing in PLA, and, if using a polyester resin for glassing the plug, well, maybe just don't. The curing process is exothermic which could be interesting - if you do though, let me know how it goes.

Hardware Requirements/Post-Printing For best results I would use a 3mm DIA x 30mm smooth hardened stainless steel rod with this part to ensure no rusting - or something with similar strength & durability characteristics. Tolerance on the hole for the insert has to be pretty close to stop any resin flowing through gaps and filling the recess so you'll probably need to heat the rod and work it in.

author: DimeGonzo

description.text:
Thingiverse has designs for one of the most diverse Space Ship fleets in "existence". It also houses one of the largest collections of unique themeatic Chess set collections (380+ and counting). This project combines the two for a "Space Ship Theme Chess Set". This is the first piece and represents an intrasystem short hop supply tanker. I hope that others might pick up on this and contribute their own ship designs (see below). Maybe even form a "collection" of space ship inspired chess pieces. If you already have a space ship design then perhaps you might add a tag to include it in this group. If you would like to contribute to this collection here are some Guildelines: Make sure you upload your design (or add this tag to your existing project) with the following exact text in the "TAGS" field: "Chess_Space_Ship_Theme". That way we can all find all of the pieces that anyone contributes for this theme by searching for that Tag. Possible "homage" designs might include a separate theme dedicated to some famous Sy-Fi ships including (TAG Chess_Space_ship_Sy_Fi_theme), the following:
  • Forbidden planet saucer
  • Halo, both sides
  • Star Trek TNG (and Original shuttles)
  • Bolo Orbital with AntiGrav Sled or ODS
  • Flash Gordon's original ship
  • Battlestar Galactica both series
  • Lost in space
  • Original space movie with musical theme by that famous guy...
  • Ship "From earth to the Moon"
  • Others?
    • Here are the design parameters if you would like to contribute a NEW design to a basic set. There can be as many designs for each pieces as there are contributors, so ultimately people can assemble peices from different contributors to create their favorite chess set. I'll update the list in this project with anyone's ideas, suggestions, ships for the Sy-Fi movie theme collection etc... Design Parameters:

  • Each piece should resemble some kind of space ship.

  • Try to Keep the lines simple and watch out for overhangs.

  • You may want to put each piece on a platform with rounded edges (like a pedestle, see this pawn).

  • Initial ideas:

    Pawn - Tanker/resupply ship, intrasystem short hops; shuttle

    Knight - Armed, possibly Bolo Series XXX+

    Bishop - Interstellar, possbily FTL drive section

    Queen - Sleeker lines, Halo covenant?

    Rook/Castle - Orbital Drop ship (ODS)/orbital build platform

    King - Maybe from ship in the Riddick series

    • Tips and tricks:

  • Drill out base or desing with a void space to fill with Wood's metal (low melting point metal), for weighting the pieces (or magnet).

  • Give an acetone vapor bath to smooth surfaces then make a latex rubber casting mold for two part plastic (MicroMark or Polytek).

  • Cast pieces in colored Plastic or even as cold cast metal using metal powders (I did aluminum and copper).

  • Use surface opalescent pigments for cast plastic parts to give a ship the titanium "Halo Covenant" look
    • This piece was designed in trueSpace CAD and printed in ABS from Octave, normal, 2 layer surface and 2 layer raft on an Up!3D.

• Download, scale and print.
  • Add wieght or a rare earth magent to base.
  • I included the dxf for anyone who wants to CNC the part.

Here are three paper weights which share the same basic form.  One is decorated with public art from Carlsbad, California; a second is decorated with pentagrams and hexagrams; and the third is left undecorated.  The plain version has three "windows" which can accept photographs or small objects.  OpenSCAD code is included.

The weights have a hole in the bottom for filling.  A base with plug can be glued in place after the weight is filled.  Zinc pennies are one of the least expensive fillings, the weights hold nearly a pound of pennies.  The base serves as a template for cutting photographs to fit the spaces in the undecorated weight.

Fix a wire - save a rack! There might be better and easier ways to fix a laundry rack,
but what's the point in doing that if you own a 3D printer? PROTIP:
Two of these clamps, combined with printing filament, can be
used to span new wires between the existing ones...

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

about 50%

Notes: Do not print the provided STL file. It is only an example.
If you are not familiar with OpenSCAD, feel free to just
edit this file in Thingiverse's Customizer. Basically, you only need to modify two variables, to create
your own, perfectly fitting Laundry Rack Repair Kit.
  • the diameter of the frame, "lrDiaFrame"
  • the diameter of the wire, "lrDiaWire"
    • Add ~0.5mm - 0.7mm to the measured values. The example STL was created with lrDiaFrame = 14.7mm lrDiaWire = 3.3mm

For a finer control, I recommend editing the OpenSCAD file
directly. It is well documented (TM) and contains a special
"Edit Mode", in which you can examine the (otherwise not
visible) holes and cutouts.

BOM 2 x 3mm nut
2 x 10x3mm screw

description.text: This is the universal spindle mount, found purchasable from the X-Carve website. It works perfectly with their spindle mounting plate. It is designed to go with a 52mm spindle, like the one they sell on their website. You can print either two or four of them. After you print these, you could use them on the machine to mill new ones out of aluminum as a temporary measure (when you get your X-Carve working with these). In the design, there is also a small flat section for mounting a 40x40 laser so you can use the mount to hold a laser module.

author: ThePiGuy

description.text:
I made a smaller version as well http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1266349
Version 2
I use this tool daily to open packages as small as an envelope or as large as a shrink wrapped pallet. It was designed with blade replacement and safety in mind. The gap is wide enough for tape, shrink wrap, paper and cardboard but not a finger. The tolerances are tight enough to hold a razor blade but I've added a small hole where the blade is inserted that lines up with the slot on the blade. A bent paper clip or I use a little piece of wire in the hole to prevent the blade from coming out. Just the tip of the top or the not sharp part of the blade sticks out the back just enough to poke through tape. It sticks out just enough to grab the blade with a pair of needle-nose pliers if the blade gets stuck. Its tight for the first few blade changes. The blade is positioned so that once it is dull it can be flipped and used again. Printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal sliced using CURA 200 degrees
.1984 layer
30 speed (I should have printed slower say 20-25)
100% infill
I printed it standing on its back without support.

title: Multicoloured Heart Box for someone special.

description.text: This was an experiment using some great colours of Faberdashery PLA filament and a different method to combine colours. Along with the joined coloured filaments I also designed cut-out sections and objects to fit into the voids, after printing these separately these were heated with a hot-air gun and pushed into the spaces, this was not as easy as I had expected due to the fact I made them sized to fit, really they need to be slightly smaller as they would be so much easier to join when warm and soft. You can see it printing in this video here - http://www.youtube.com/user/RichRap2011#p/a/u/0/lrJPJDvobFI More info on my blog - www.richrap.blogspot.com

Print out all the parts and join them together, I used a heat-gun and melted them all to fit.
If you want the striped effect you need to join lengths of filament together - see my filament joiner - 
If you don't have someone special with an 'A' as their name, you may want to edit the sketchup files.

description.text:
A vibration reducing GoPro camera mount for the AQ600 quad copter frame.  
Created using my hobby software cad implementation. Source for this thing will be released as soon as the cad program is in a releasable state.

You will need
  • The printed parts.
  • Some material acting as vibration reducer, I used some kind of foam rubber but there are probably other and even better materials to use.
  • Tie raps to keep the parts together. (See image)
  • M5 Screw and nut to fasten the GoPro camera.
  • Two M3 screws and nuts to fasten the mount on your quad.
  • And of cause a GoPro camera (I use a Hero3 but this mount should be compatible with all variants) and optionally one of the extension arms to enable tilting of the camera sideways.
    • I printed the parts in ABS using 30% infill.

comments.text: Nicely done. Really clever use of zip ties. I'll have to be sure and buy good quality ones though. I've had them fail on me before.

Notes: Corner to corner like the connivers kunai. The blade in this is a lot bigger than the connivers, so to make sure the handle is big enough for your hand, make it as big as you can.

I got one made My teacher is the one who owns a 3d printer, and it made me get into modelling and the printer itself. I'm guessing all 3d printers have a cost calculator, and i gave him this model and gave him the money it calculated and got it print on october 23rd 2015. I now have provided a picture of it. For when it was printed, the two peices coming off of where the handle meet the blade came off(although i think the bigger one was my fault) as well as the handle. If you see little bits of light glare, that's gorilla glue. I will be making a change that resulted in a hollow hole in the top of the handle.

Tip of Blade If you look in thingiview, you can see that the tip of the blade is very very thin. If you want this changed, please comment to tell me whether or not. If you think it is unimportant to change, tell me ways i could improve the print settings section so that you can lay it out in a way to make the tip very powerful.

author: dhulihan

title: Generic Belt Clip Adaptor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Because I'm considering several different clippable things for belts, I figured a basic, modular part for clipping things was in order. This clip has a slot at the top which is continuous through its length, in addition to a deep cutout for the belt itself. This should make it easy to design things that slot into this gap for clip-on functionality. Click the thumbnail to the left for a better view with the default dimensions (assuming the export plugin worked correctly)
  • Update: I've added a correctly-sized "plug" to the sketchup file and as an .stl. It should fit quite nicely, and could either be printed independently of another item and glued/welded on, or attached to a model before printing.
Check the dimensions against your intended belt; they should be pretty one-size fits all at present but it's best to be sure. Scale the plug to match!

comments.text: I designed another modular wearable mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1748 ), with a different interfacing scheme. Want to try to standardize on something?

author: cathalgarvey

description.text: This was an experiment using some great coloured Faberdashery PLA filament. It was not just designed to look pretty as I added lots of sections for filament bridging and thin layers for colour change. Skeinforge finds bridging on curves hard as it decided on an angle for the direction of bridge and does the whole section the same angle, so at points along the curve filament is going straight into the gap, this makes it a hard test especially when done at high speed, thatâ€™s why you can see a few gaps and dips in the model surface. I could make it look much better with a different Rainbow design but this was testing how the filament would perform on my Prusa Mendel â€˜Blingâ€™ machine. You can see it printing in this video here - http://www.youtube.com/user/RichRap2011#p/a/u/1/UA97cC1QfM8 More info on my Blog - www.richrap.blogspot.com

You really need to print it out with multiple sections of coloured filament, if you just print in one colour it will look a bit boring.
Take a look at how to make a filament joiner under the other things I have made.

comments.text: nice one! you're pushing the multicolor stuff - really enjoying your blog. keep up the great work!

author: gowdy

description.text:
This fence was designed for my 12” Delta model 28-190 bandsaw. It clamps at both ends to an aluminum angle stock which was bolted to the bandsaw table. The levers rock open to release the clamp. The SketchUp file is included.
Slic3r was used to generate G-code.

comments.text:
hello
Nice work! But what type/size of aluminium did you use?
What are the nut for size and where to find the angled pin your using?
Just want to get an idea so I can make it to fit my home made table that is under construction!
Thanks in advance //Andreas
comments.author: Mcgyver

comments.text:
I used pieces of 1" angled extruded aluminum. The thickness is 1/8" (pretty standard here at home improvement stores).
The clamping mechanism is forgiving on thickness and you can adjust the separation between clamps to account for larger angle stock.
All the bolts, hardware, and assembly instructions are in the included file BandsawFence.pdf.
I love the clamping mechanism but my assembly can be a little finnicky. Perhaps enlarging the bolt holes would help.
Also, the fence does not run true / perpendicular on its own. I need to adjust both ends. For my light work it functions great !
BTW - as you are building your own table, you might checkout my miter gage as well: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:505852

description.text: This is my version of a cooling fan shroud for the MakerGear M2's stock 50 mm cooling fan assembly. This is a bolt-on upgrade for the cooling fan which directs the cooling air toward the print and away from the heater block which can rob power from the heater unnecessarily. The shroud was printed with ABS to resist deforming from the heat created from the heated print bed. I designed this file with FreeCAD and is my first attempt at a semi-complex model. I hope someone finds it useful. Thanks for checking out my contribution to Thigiverse!!!

author: amats

title: mpcnc corner block remake IE and EMT versions

description.text:
UPDATE 20 /10/15
Uploaded 23.45 outside diameter tube version,for US EMT conduit sized tube/pipe. This is a complete remake of the mostly printed CNC corner support block.
This corner block supports 25.4mm tube/pipe.
You will need 4 x m5 nuts and bolts @ 80mm per corner,to clamp down on both tubes in the same instance. The four bolts in each corner support,will allow for greater torque and minimize the risk of De-lamination of the printed parts.
Belt tension-er brackets are fitted prior to bolts being fitted through the assembly,thereby holding all components securely with just the four M5 X 80mm bolts. I use abs for printing and rework holes with a drill bit for a better finish. UPDATE 17/10/15 added belt clip. Please print out 2 x FR LEFT BK RIGHT and 2 x FR RIGHT BK LEFT also print 8x belt clips. This design will enable you to use an hook eye on each belt for easier adjustments. UPDATE 18/10/15 build photos added,it all went together has expected.
Now just waiting for the eye bolts to arrive to complete the assembly. Enjoy.
More complete remakes coming soon,,) Many thanks go to allted for your inspiring design,pure genius.

comments.text: Printed 4 of them.. They all broke due to tightness.  Reprinting laying on side with Support.  Also, scaled to 1.03 so the pipes fit in the holes.  Using Standard 3/4 Inch Electric Conduit with the 23.45mm stl...

Awesome
I'm really glad you like the design.
I tried to simplify and strengthen the original corner support block,and I'm pleased with the way it turned out.
Everything is held really tight and you don't need to worry about cracking your print whilst applying torque on the bolts.
The bolts clamp down on all layers of the print and will prevent delamination under high load.

I shall make the inner dimensions 23.45 to ensure adequate clamping force is applied to the tubes whilst being torqued up.

I suggest that you post this as a remix of both the IE and EMT versions so that others will see it from the main pages. I think there will be a lot of interest.
SteveC

author: rahul1996

title: Heavy duty Nema 23 Bowden Extruder sandwich plate

description.text: In my quest to make a Bowden extruder for the DaVinci 1.0 that will not stall (click) I used a huge 5Nm Nema 23. This has a 10mm shaft which I have not found an extruder gear of suitable size, so I had a converter made by a local engineer in steel, converting 10mm shaft -> 5mm. I then made this sandwich plate to accept a Nema 17 extruder spaced appropriately for a Nema 23 motor.

comments.text: Did the clicking stop?
comments.author: Eddiie

comments.text: Short answer is yes, but even with this extruder you can make it click by winding the print speed up too much, putting down too thick a layer and/or having the hot end too cool.

author: headless

description.text:
You will find a lot of charging boxed made by wood for Apple watch and iPhone. Unfortunately the phone docking is kept very universal (at least in the version I got). Therefore you have to plugin/unplug the cable manually for each charging session. The following extension can be used for iPhone 5/6/6s (lightning connector). The iPhone stands on the connector and can be easily plugged in and removed.
It's made out of 3mm birch plywood and cut by 40W CO2 Laser.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: The cut data is in layer 'Cut' and the engrave information in layer 'Engrave'. Easy to handle if you use VisitCut (http://hci.rwth-aachen.de/visicut). The laser parameter for my 40W CO2 laser cutter are:
Engrave --> power = 21%, Speed = 100%
Cut --> power = 100%, speed = 4%
After cutting just glue the 9 parts together with wood glue. The order is (obvious)
  • Top part with engrave
  • 3 x vertical hole (around the connector)
  • 3 x horizontal hole (around the cable, you have to turn it 90° when mounting)
  • part with open hole (bend the cable by 90°)
  • part w/o hole
    Good luck!

title: MPCNC Endstop Clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is clamps for 25mm conduit (but I believe that you can clamp it over US also). Printed from ABS (for higher flexibility) with 30% infill.
You can screw endstops on this clam and move them on right position on selected conduit (I have them on X/Y for min/max and Z max)
Very usable for relative coordinates and machines with flexible sizes of working area - you don't need to be afraid that your machine will run into hard stop because you will limit it by endstops and not by size.
Don't forget to activate endstops in Marlin configuration!!

comments.text: The diameter of the opening for the rail is a bit too wide. You can probably press-fit it by applying enough force, but a somewhat better fit would be nice. And a higher resolution for the circular wall would also be nice - now, the contact area is limited to the center of the segments. I printed the part in PLA. Yes, a very well calibrated printer, Allted's parts show a snug fit to the rails. Apart from that, a nice design.

title: Angle Mount for Acer K132 LED Projector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a projector angle clamp that I made for my Structured Light Scanning Rig. I use the David 3D scanning software. This clamps to a 1.5" x 1.5" right angle 1/8" aluminum rail or it can mount on a tripod. There is a little over 15 degree range of movement with the locking
straps or 90 degrees without. The 5.1 mm holes are tapped with a 1/4 - 20 thread. I recommend at least 3 perimeter shells to allow for the tap to thread properly. I printed the top in 3 different settings using Simplify 3D. The first 5 mm @ .1 & 30%, the next 6 mm @ .1 & 50%, and the 13 mm @ .1 & 100% infill. It took over 9 hours to print. It may be overkill, but there is no kill like overkill LOL. Being a machinist, I based this design on a 5" Sine Plate. You can calculate the angle you desire based on the sine function with a constant of 2". For example:
sine of 30 deg x 2" = 1"
or in metric:
sine of 30 deg x 50.8 mm = 25.4 mm So, you would place a shim (gage block or pin) under the raised 6 mm radius end of the top plate equal to 1" or 25.4 mm to give you an angle of 30 degrees. This is only
approximate due to the quality of your 3D print and the bearing surface of the hinge.
I have included a sine plate proof to elaborate on the mechanics of a sine plate. Hardware: 3/4" & 1-1/4" machine screws

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

title: Lm8uu quick release carriage for Prusa Mendel

description.text: So I wanted a quick change X carriage that allows me to leave alone the bushings and rods, as much as possible. Also, I am printing PLA, and there are just too many reports of melted/warped/softened X carriages floating around to be at ease with a PLA carriage. However, this should not be a problem with the bushing holders because of the heatsinking effect of metal. I like GregFrost's three bushings X-carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9869 , but I think the side with two bushings should be positioned near the belt, and not the opposite way. Note: this mod adds about 6 mm to the extruder base height. As I have verified with use, this does not interfere with "standard" hotends (I'm using ParCans design).

Adopted solution uses 5.7 mm routed plywood and six 8mm diam x 6 mm high cylindric magnets (if you are paranoid you can get heat-resistant versions on eBay at little price difference), three per plate. Magnets are fixed with cyanoacrylate glue before the epoxy treatment. Plywood was soaked in marine epoxy and allowed to cure, the surface is very resistant. Boltheads are used to secure position with corresponding holes in the upper plates. While the holding force provided by the magnets is pretty strong, "just in case" I left also two holes for pass-through bolts. I used three of GregFrost's LM8UU holders not bolted (IMHO bolting defeats the whole purpose of gluing), but epoxied to the carriage according to standard procedure.
The zip ties were pre-positioned then tightened before the curing process. The upper carriage features "standard" GregFrost's fixations. Just add quick connectors to the extruder, and (hopefully) you'll be able to change the whole upper plate-extruder block in less than a minute.

description.text:
This is a horse-shoe shaped pen & ink stand for fountain pens, pencils or paintbrushes.
Includes a 14 pen capacity with four of the holes being over-sized to hold larger pens.  Also includes an inkwell inset and a cap holder for pens that you prefer not to post.
This is version 1.0 of the Horse-shoe Stand...
Please provide feedback if you download and print this item! It let's me know if you would like to see more designs for writing enthusiasts!
Future bases will include different sized/shaped slots for other ink bottles.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Include at least 5 solid layers on the top to ensure the posts don't pull off when attempting to remove the base from your printbed. Don't use the posts to attempt to pull the base off of your print bed if at all possible... Print horse-show with inset holes facing up and print the base with the posts facing up. This assembly simply snaps together. No glue or other accessories are necessary for assembly.

title: Angle Mount for Custom C615 camera case

description.text: I made this for my Structured Light 3D scanning rig. I use David 3D scanning software. I modified the Logitech C615 custom camera case using the info from the following link. http://forum.david-3d.com/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=5863 The bracket clamps to a 1.5" x 1.5" right angle 1/8" aluminum rail or it can mount on a tripod. The camera mount can rotate 30 degrees side to side. The 5.1 mm holes are tapped with a 1/4 - 20 thread. I recommend at least 3 perimeter shells to allow for the tap to thread properly.

remixed_from.author: DIYElectronics
remixed_from.title: CharlStruder For E3D and J-Head on Prusa i3

description.text:
I designed this for a 60mm fam. It will NOT work any other size fan, that's why I included the dxf in case someone would like to modify the bracket. It's designed to mount to the front of the CharlStruder (see link below) and it will work with some variants of the Greg Wade Extruder.
I know 60mm might be bit big, but it' the only spare fan I had. You can control the Min/Max speeds in your slicer settings if it's getting a bit too cold.
This is not really a remix, but more of an add-on.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Print Speed: 40mm/s It's only a fan holder, so doesn't need to look AMAZING. Also the light is very light so it doesn't need to be super strong. Use your discretion with your slicer settings.

Design of 60mm Fan Holder I use a program called HeeksCNC. I found it while looking for programs to use with my CNC Engraver. It's an open sourced CAD/CAM software that's simple to use for 3D modelling. I do alot of designing with it, and it parts print perfectly. Check out the link if you want to know more https://code.google.com/p/heekscnc/
